title: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
scope: ** Evaluation and management of carpal tunnel syndrome from initial presentation through conservative treatment, injection therapy, and surgical referral. Covers clinical diagnosis, electrodiagnostic testing, severity grading, and treatment options. For acute median nerve injury or severe CTS with thenar atrophy, early surgical referral is indicated.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Screen for diabetes (common CTS risk factor)

Extended Workup.rationale: More specific for RA if RF negative
Renal disease (dialysis-associated CTS from amyloid deposition)
Amyloidosis, myeloma (bilateral CTS may be presenting sign of AL amyloid)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: AL amyloidosis if bilateral CTS with cardiac/renal involvement
Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis if young onset bilateral CTS
Bilateral CTS in patient with acromegalic features

Referrals & Consults.item: Hand surgery or orthopedic surgery referral for carpal tunnel release evaluation when conservative therapy fails or severe CTS present
Electrodiagnostic medicine/neurology for NCS/EMG to confirm diagnosis and grade severity before surgical intervention
Occupational medicine for workplace ergonomic assessment and work restrictions if occupational risk factors present
Physical/occupational therapy for nerve gliding exercises, ergonomic training, and activity modification
Rheumatology referral if inflammatory arthritis suspected as underlying cause (RA, gout)
Endocrinology for diabetes optimization or hypothyroidism management if contributing to CTS
Primary care for management of modifiable risk factors (diabetes, obesity, hypothyroidism)
Pain management if refractory neuropathic symptoms despite treatment

Patient Instructions.item: Wear wrist splint nightly in neutral position for minimum 4-6 weeks; may wear during day if symptoms persist with activities
Avoid prolonged wrist flexion or extension (typing, gripping tools, driving) as this increases carpal tunnel pressure
Take frequent breaks during repetitive hand activities (every 30-60 minutes) to rest wrists
Perform nerve gliding exercises as instructed by therapist to improve median nerve mobility
Apply ice for 10-15 minutes if wrist swelling present; avoid direct ice contact with skin
Report worsening numbness, weakness in thumb, or dropping objects (may indicate progression requiring surgery)
Avoid sleeping with wrists curled under pillow; maintain neutral wrist position during sleep
If pregnant, symptoms often improve after delivery; conservative management preferred during pregnancy
After corticosteroid injection, temporary increase in symptoms may occur first 24-48 hours before improvement
Post-surgical: Keep incision clean and dry; elevate hand; start motion as directed; full grip strength recovery may take 3-6 months

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Optimize glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) as diabetes worsens nerve function and CTS outcomes
Weight loss if overweight/obese as obesity is modifiable risk factor for CTS
Ergonomic workstation setup: keyboard at elbow height, wrists neutral, avoid resting wrists on hard surfaces
Use ergonomic keyboard, mouse, and tools if occupation involves repetitive hand use
Smoking cessation to improve microvascular circulation and nerve healing
Avoid prolonged use of vibrating tools or take breaks every 15-30 minutes when using such equipment
Reduce caffeine and alcohol intake as these may worsen paresthesias in some patients
Treat underlying thyroid disease as hypothyroidism contributes to CTS through tissue edema
Stretch and warm up hands before repetitive activities
Vitamin B6 supplementation not recommended (evidence does not support benefit; high doses cause neuropathy)

differential.features: Neck pain, dermatomal pattern (not strictly median), reflex changes (C6: brachioradialis; C7: triceps), negative Phalen/Tinel
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine; NCS/EMG shows radicular pattern; neck range of motion limited

differential.features: Forearm pain/tenderness at pronator teres, symptoms with resisted pronation, no nocturnal worsening, palmar cutaneous branch affected
differential.tests: NCS/EMG; tenderness at pronator teres on exam; provocative testing

differential.features: Weakness only (FPL, FDP to index, pronator quadratus); no sensory loss; pinch weakness
differential.tests: NCS/EMG; cannot make "OK" sign (pinch between thumb and index)

differential.features: Shoulder/arm pain, positional symptoms, vascular symptoms (pallor, cyanosis), C8-T1 distribution
differential.tests: Adson test; ROOS test; X-ray for cervical rib; MRA; NCS

differential.features: Numbness in ring and small finger, hand weakness, elbow symptoms, positive Tinel at elbow
differential.tests: NCS/EMG shows ulnar slowing at elbow; sensory exam (ulnar digits spared in CTS)

differential.features: Symmetric symptoms, length-dependent, feet often affected first, multiple nerve territories
differential.tests: NCS shows generalized abnormalities; HbA1c; B12; metabolic panel

differential.features: Radial wrist pain, positive Finkelstein test, no numbness, tenderness over 1st dorsal compartment
differential.tests: Finkelstein test positive; ultrasound shows tendon thickening; no NCS abnormalities

differential.features: Color changes (white-blue-red), cold-triggered, bilateral, no weakness
differential.tests: No NCS abnormalities; may have positive ANA; capillaroscopy

differential.features: Shoulder/arm weakness and sensory loss in plexus pattern, may have Horner syndrome
differential.tests: NCS/EMG; MRI brachial plexus; distribution beyond median nerve

differential.features: Finger locking/clicking, palm nodule, no numbness in median distribution
differential.tests: Palpable nodule at A1 pulley; no NCS abnormalities; triggering on exam

differential.features: Palpable mass, may transilluminate, compresses median nerve
differential.tests: Ultrasound or MRI shows cystic structure; NCS may be normal or show CTS

differential.features: Central demyelination; other neurologic symptoms; sensory symptoms may mimic CTS
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine; CSF oligoclonal bands; NCS normal

differential.features: Dissociated sensory loss (pain/temp preserved, vibration lost), cape distribution, central cord lesion
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine shows syrinx cavity

differential.features: Bilateral CTS, cardiac involvement, macroglossia, renal disease, family history (hATTR)
differential.tests: SPEP/UPEP; free light chains; TTR gene; tissue biopsy

evidence.recommendation: Nocturnal wrist splinting is effective first-line treatment for CTS
evidence.source: [Page MJ et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22786497/)

evidence.recommendation: NCS/EMG recommended for diagnostic confirmation before surgery
Corticosteroid injection provides short-term symptom relief
evidence.source: [Marshall S et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17253462/)

evidence.recommendation: Carpal tunnel release surgery is effective for moderate-severe CTS
evidence.source: [Verdugo RJ et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18843658/)

evidence.recommendation: Ultrasound-guided injection improves accuracy and outcomes
evidence.source: [Ustun N et al. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2013](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23267555/)

evidence.recommendation: Diabetes mellitus is significant risk factor for CTS
Clinical examination (Phalen, Tinel) has moderate sensitivity/specificity
evidence.source: [Middleton SD et al. J Hand Surg Eur Vol 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23824222/)

evidence.recommendation: Severe CTS with thenar atrophy should be referred for surgery
evidence.source: [Graham B et al. J Am Acad Orthop Surg 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26803543/)

evidence.recommendation: Endoscopic and open CTR have equivalent long-term outcomes
evidence.source: [Scholten RJ et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17943857/)

evidence.recommendation: Median nerve CSA >10-12 mm² on ultrasound supports CTS diagnosis
Nerve gliding exercises may provide modest benefit as adjunct therapy
evidence.source: [Ballestero-Perez R et al. J Orthop Sports Phys Ther 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28622488/)

AANEM practice parameter for electrodiagnosis of CTS

monitoring.action: Consider escalation: injection if splinting fails; surgery if injection fails

monitoring.frequency: Baseline and q4-8 weeks if weakness
monitoring.action: Expedite surgical referral if progressive weakness
If atrophy developing, urgent surgical referral (indicates severe CTS)
If abnormal/worsening, indicates sensory axonal loss; consider surgery
Re-educate; consider injection if compliant but not improving
If no improvement, discuss surgical options
If infection signs, antibiotics and wound care
If not improving, NCS/EMG; consider incomplete release or scarring
NCS; consider revision surgery if confirmed recurrence

disposition.criteria: Mild-moderate CTS; can use splint; outpatient neurology/hand surgery follow-up arranged; no thenar atrophy; no progressive weakness
Acute compartment syndrome of forearm/hand (rare); post-operative complication requiring observation; severe medical comorbidities requiring inpatient management
Not typical for CTS; only if concurrent critical illness
Thenar atrophy; progressive weakness; constant numbness with sensory loss; failed conservative therapy >6 months; severe CTS on NCS with denervation
Moderate CTS with inadequate response to splinting and injection; patient preference; occupational impairment
Most patients; splinting trial with reassessment in 4-6 weeks; post-injection follow-up in 2-4 weeks
